ClinicalTitle: Surgical site infections from colon surgery (SSI: Colon)
WebName: Infections after colon surgery
Description: Colon surgery removes diseased or damaged parts of the colon. Sometimes the area of the body where the surgery takes place can become infected. This can involve the skin, tissues under the skin, organs, or implanted material. These infections can cause serious problems and even death. A high number of infections may mean the hospital is not doing a good job at preventing infections.
ConsumerDescription: Colon surgery removes diseased or damaged parts of the colon. Sometimes the area of the body where the surgery takes place can become infected. This can involve the skin, tissues under the skin, organs, or implanted material. These infections can cause serious problems and even death. A high number of infections may mean the hospital is not doing a good job at preventing infections.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Infections after colon surgery

ClinicalTitle: Surgical site infections from abdominal hysterectomy (SSI: Hysterectomy)
WebName: Infections after hysterectomy
Description: A hysterectomy is a surgery to removes the uterus. Sometimes the area of the body where the surgery takes place can become infected. This can involve the skin, tissues under the skin, organs, or implanted material. These infections can cause serious problems and even death. A high number of infections may mean the hospital is not doing a good job at preventing infections.
ConsumerDescription: A hysterectomy is a surgery to removes the uterus. Sometimes the area of the body where the surgery takes place can become infected. ConsumerPlainTitle: Infections after hysterectomy

ClinicalTitle: Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI)
WebName: Central Line-associated Blood Stream Infections (CLABSI)
Description:
A central line is a long, narrow, flexible tube or catheter inserted into a large vein, ending at or close to the heart. The central line is placed in order to give medications, fluids, nutrients or blood products, to obtain blood tests, or to obtain cardiovascular measurements over a long period of time. When not put in correctly or kept clean, central lines can cause serious infections in the blood. These are called central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs). They can cause hospital stays to be longer and increase the risk of death.

Hospitals can prevent vascular central line-associated infections by choosing the best sites for inserting the catheter, using the right catheter material, keeping the site clean, and removing the catheter when it is no longer needed. Hospitals with high rates of this complication may not be following these recommended procedures.
ConsumerDescription:
A central line is a long, narrow, flexible tube or catheter inserted into a large vein, ending at or close to the heart. The central line is placed in order to give medications, fluids, nutrients or blood products, to obtain blood tests, or to obtain cardiovascular measurements over a long period of time. When not put in correctly or kept clean, central lines can cause serious infections in the blood. These are called central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs). They can cause hospital stays to be longer and increase the risk of death.

Hospitals can prevent vascular central line-associated infections by choosing the best sites for inserting the catheter, using the right catheter material, keeping the site clean, and removing the catheter when it is no longer needed. Hospitals with high rates of this complication may not be following these recommended procedures.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Bloodstream infections from central line catheters

ClinicalTitle: Catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI)
WebName: Catheter-associated urinary tract infections
Description: Catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI)
ConsumerDescription: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection involving any part of the urinary system, including urethra, bladder, ureters, and kidney. UTIs are one of the most common type of infection acquired a healthcare facility  Among UTIs acquired in the hospital, most associated with a urinary catheter, which is a tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine.  Between 15-25% of hospitalized patients receive urinary catheters during their hospital stay.  The most important risk factor for developing an infection is prolonged use of the urinary catheter.  Therefore, catheters should only be used for appropriate indications and should be removed as soon as they are no longer needed.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Urinary tract infections from catheters

ClinicalTitle: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (or MRSA) blood infections
WebName: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) infections
Description: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (or MRSA) blood infections.
ConsumerDescription: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (or MRSA) is a type of staph bacteria that is resistant to many antibiotics. In a hospital, MRSA can cause severe problems such as bloodstream infections, pneumonia and surgical site infections.  When healthcare providers follow  appropriate guidelines, MRSA infections can largely, if not completely, be prevented.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) infections

ClinicalTitle: Clostridium difficile (or C.diff.) infections
WebName: Clostridium difficile (C.diff.) infections
Description: Clostridium difficile (or C.diff.) infections.
ConsumerDescription: Clostridium difficile (C. diff) is an infection that can cause diarrhea. Most cases of C. diff infection occur in patients taking antibiotics.  C. diff infection can spread from person-to-person on contaminated equipment and on the hands of doctors, nurses, other healthcare providers and visitors. If proper precautions are taken, the number of C. diff infections can be reduced.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Clostridium difficile (C.diff.) infections

ClinicalTitle: Immunization for influenza
WebName: Patients in the hospital who got the flu vaccine if they were likely to get flu
Description: This prevention measure addresses acute care hospitalized inpatients age 6 months and older who were screened for seasonal influenza immunization status and were vaccinated prior to discharge if indicated. The numerator captures two activities: screening and the intervention of vaccine administration when indicated. As a result, patients who had documented contraindications to the vaccine, patients who were offered and declined the vaccine and patients who received the vaccine during the current year?s influenza season but prior to the current hospitalization are captured as numerator events
ConsumerDescription: This quality rating includes hospitalized patients age 6 months and older who were asked if they had previously received for a seasonal flu vaccine and were vaccinated prior to leaving the hospital.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Patients in the hospital who got the flu vaccine if they were likely to get flu

ClinicalTitle: Acute myocardial infarction (AMI) 30-day mortality rate
WebName: Dying within 30-days after getting care in the hospital for a heart attack

These rates show how many patients died within 30 days of going to the hospital for a heart attack, and takes into account how sick patients were before they went to the hospital.

ClinicalTitle: Simultaneous use of brain computed tomography (CT) and sinus CT
WebName: Patients who came to the hospital for a scan of their brain and also got a scan of their sinuses.
Description: A brain computed tomography (CT) is often ordered in addition to a sinus CT because headache is a common symptom related to sinusitis. However, both a CT sinus and brain imaging for headache on the same day without suspected complications is generally considered inappropriate. Performing both scans is duplicative and results in inefficiency, lower quality care, and poses potential risk for patients who are exposed to more radiation.
ConsumerDescription: A brain computed tomography (CT) is often ordered in addition to a sinus CT because headache is a common symptom related to sinusitis. ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should give surgery patients antibiotics within 1 hour before surgery. Antibiotics are medicines that fight infections in your body which, given properly, can greatly lower your chances of getting an infection after surgery.

ClinicalTitle: Prophylactic antibiotic selection for surgical patients
WebName: Right antibiotics given to surgery patients
Description: Hospital staff should give surgery patients the right kind of antibiotics to lower the chance of infection after surgery. The right antibiotic for a patient depends on the kind of surgery they had.
ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should give surgery patients the right kind of antibiotics to lower the chance of infection after surgery. The right antibiotic for a patient depends on the kind of surgery they had.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Right antibiotics given to surgery patients

ClinicalTitle: Prophylactic antibiotics discontinued within 24 hours after surgery end time
WebName: Antibiotics stopped within 24 hours after surgery
Description: Hospital staff should stop giving antibiotics to surgery patients within 24 hours after some surgeries because this increases the chances of side effects such as stomach problems and severe diarrhea.
ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should stop giving antibiotics to surgery patients within 24 hours after some surgeries because this increases the chances of side effects such as stomach problems and severe diarrhea.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Antibiotics stopped within 24 hours after surgery

ClinicalTitle: Cardiac Surgery Patients with Controlled 6AM Postoperative Blood Glucose
WebName: Blood sugar level controlled after heart surgery
Description: Hospital staff should help surgery patients keep their blood sugar as close to normal as possible after their surgery, because this can lower their chances of infections, heart attack, and brain, kidney, lung, and stomach problems.
ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should help surgery patients keep their blood sugar as close to normal as possible after their surgery, because this can lower their chances of infections, heart attack, and brain, kidney, lung, and stomach problems.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Blood sugar level controlled after heart surgery

ClinicalTitle: Urinary catheter removed on postoperative day 1 (POD 1) or postoperative day 2 (POD 2) with day of surgery being day zero
WebName: Urinary catheters removed on the first or second day after surgery
Description: Hospital staff should remove urinary catheters, which is a tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine, from surgery patients on the first or second day after surgery.
ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should remove urinary catheters, which is a tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine, from surgery patients on the first or second day after surgery.

ClinicalTitle: Surgery patients with perioperative temperature management
WebName: Preventing low body temperature during and after surgery
Description: Hospital staff should manage patients' body temperature during and after surgery.
ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should manage patients' body temperature during and after surgery.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Preventing low body temperature during and after surgery

ClinicalTitle: Surgery patients who received appropriate venous thromboembolism prophylaxis within 24 hours prior to surgery to 24 hours after surgery
WebName: Surgery patients prescribed treatment to prevent blood clots at the right time
Description: Hospital staff should give surgery patients treatment to prevent blood clots within 24 hours before and after certain surgeries. These treatments include blood-thinning medicines and special stockings that help blood move through the body.
ConsumerDescription: Hospital staff should give surgery patients treatment to prevent blood clots within 24 hours before and after certain surgeries. These treatments include blood-thinning medicines and special stockings that help blood move through the body.

ClinicalTitle: Incidence of potentially preventable VTE
WebName: Patients who developed a blood clot while in the hospital and did not get treatment that could have prevented it
Description: This measure assesses the number of patients diagnosed with confirmed VTE during hospitalization (not present at admission) who did not receive VTE prophylaxis between hospital admission and the day before the VTE diagnostic testing order date

Description: COPD is a lung disease that blocks airflow and makes it hard to breathe. A high number of deaths after leaving the hospital related to care for a COPD may mean the hospital is not treating people effectively for these conditions.

Description: The survey asked patients about how well they understood the information they got before they left the hospital. Hospital staff should talk to patients about the care they will need at home and give them information on symptoms and health problems to watch for.

ClinicalTitle: Safe surgery checklist use
WebName: Hospital uses a Safe Surgery Checklist for outpatient surgeries
Description: Hospitals can help reduce the number of surgical complications and deaths by using a safe surgery checklist. A safe surgery checklist which includes safe surgery practices during each of the three critical perioperative periods: 1) The period prior to the administration of anesthesia; 2) The period prior to skin incision; and 3) The period of closure of incision and prior to patient leaving the operating room.
ConsumerDescription: Hospitals can help reduce the number of surgical complications and deaths by using a safe surgery checklist. A safe surgery checklist which includes safe surgery practices during each of the three critical perioperative periods: 1) The period prior to the administration of anesthesia; 2) The period prior to skin incision; and 3) The period of closure of incision and prior to patient leaving the operating room.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Hospital uses a Safe Surgery Checklist for outpatient surgeries

ClinicalTitle: CABG Surgery 30 day readmission rate
WebName: Returning to the hospital after a procedure to bypass blocked blood vessels in the heart within 30 days after being discharged
Description: How often patients return to the hospital within 30-days after having a procedure called a coronary artery bypass graft, or CABG, which is designed to restore the natural flow of blood in the heart. Hospitals keep track of how many of their patients had to go back to the hospital soon after having a procedure (this is called a readmission rate). Readmission rates show how a hospital is doing to prevent complications, provide clear discharge instructions, and help patients make a smooth transition out of the hospital. Patients may need to return to the hospital because of their recent procedure or for a different reason.
ConsumerDescription: How often patients return to the hospital within 30-days after having a procedure called a coronary artery bypass graft, or CABG, which is designed to restore the natural flow of blood in the heart. Hospitals keep track of how many of their patients had to go back to the hospital soon after having a procedure (this is called a readmission rate). Readmission rates show how a hospital is doing to prevent complications, provide clear discharge instructions, and help patients make a smooth transition out of the hospital. Patients may need to return to the hospital because of their recent procedure or for a different reason.
ConsumerPlainTitle: Returning to the hospital after a procedure to bypass blocked blood vessels in the heart within 30 days after being discharged

ClinicalTitle: Overall Rating
WebName: CMS Hospital Compare Overall National Rating
Description:
What is the overall rating?

The overall rating combines the results of 64 individual ratings including how well the hospital takes care of patients who have conditions such as heart attack, stroke, and pneumonia; how often patients die in the hospital while receiving care; patient experiences of care; and how safely the hospital provides care. The overall rating shows how well each hospital performed, on average, compared to other hospitals in the U.S. The overall rating ranges from one to five stars. More stars are better.

How can I use the overall rating?

The overall rating can provide a starting point for comparing hospitals in your area. Use the overall rating to help you select which hospitals you would like to learn more about. Then, use the individual ratings to help you choose the best hospital for you or your family.

Where does the overall rating come from?

Hospitals report data to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). To learn more about how the overall rating is calculated, visit the CMS website. 

Why is the overall rating not displayed for some hospitals?

For an overall rating to appear for a hospital, the hospital must have enough data on the individual ratings used to calculate the overall rating. Some hospitals may not report all of their data or may not have enough data to report, and as a result, an overall star rating cannot be calculated.'
